Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Apparent competition or anthropogenic over-harvest: hunting in a multi-species context and its impact on species extinctions in Tropical East Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests contain most of the world's bird and mammal species, many of which are heavily threatened by overhunting. This project seeks to understand how habitat loss and hunting synergistically affect vertebrate communities. Doctoral Dissertation Improvement funds will complement ongoing research by supporting the collection of detailed information on hunter decision-making behavior, including hunter motivations, their prey preferences, and their searching strategies. The motivation for hunting - whether for subsistence livelihood, commercial markets, or recreation - can determine whether or not excessive hunting is likely to occur. Improved understanding of hunting behavior, in combination with spatial distribution patterns of different species, will improve management of hunting throughout the tropics, as well as in other low-governance areas. Such areas are often committed to the conflicting goals of biodiversity preservation and access by low-income rural populations to natural resources. The project will focus on capacity building and knowledge exchange with local partner institutions, ranging from protected area administration to research stations with local Chinese and Laotian graduate students and faculty. It will contribute significantly to training a graduate student by supporting the integration of social science surveys with existing field research to address an increasing problem.

A field study focusing on hunters and a suite of tropical bird species, ranging from species that are widely distributed and rarely hunted to those that have been heavily hunted and occur only in isolated fragments, will be conducted in Tropical East Asia. The investigators posit that the failure of current models to manage exploited populations results from the fact that hunting occurs in a multi-prey context. Common, unprotected prey species can subsidize the exploitation of rare species, a phenomenon called opportunistic exploitation. The researchers will adapt multi-species competition and predation models to include anthropogenic hunting, thereby offering novel predictors for vulnerability to over-exploitation. Point count transects will describe the abundance and distribution patterns of avian species within and around protected areas in Southwest China and Northern Laos. Household interviews of villagers living within 5km of protected areas will be conducted to assess hunter behavioral motivations, and hunting techniques and intensity. The field survey data will inform a mathematical model of multi-species hunting to better understand how to conserve tropical diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The supported research elucidates complex feedback loops between harvesters and natural resources to generate better approaches for conservation. The research findings demonstrate why current policing strategies to combat overhunting have failed. We developed alternative empirical measures and mathematical models to devise effective conservation strategies across a wide range of low-governance regions.

Problem background.—Overexploitation is one of the most prominent threats facing IUCN Red-Listed mammals and birds, particularly in the tropics. Classical bio-economic models focused on single species have proposed techniques for managing exploited populations, and dynamical explanations for why species are sometimes harvested to extinction. Unfortunately, such models and empirical measures based on these principles have failed to prevent population collapse. We posited that this is due to the fact that hunting exploits multiple prey species simultaneously, particularly in open-access systems typical of the developing world. Moreover, the assumption that hunting is driven by economic or subsistence aims may be inaccurate.

Findings.—The NSF supported fieldwork and interview data in Southwest China indicate that hunting activity is now largely sustained by resilient ungulate and passerine stocks; as hunting activity has continued unabated, more sensitive species have declined or have even been extirpated. We found that recreation was the main motivator of hunting, which may be widespread in the developing world but heretofore underappreciated. Recreational hunters may be less likely to reduce effort when prey populations and catch decline, increasing the likelihood of hunting-driven extirpations.

Monitoring the incidence of conservation crimes largely depends on human subjects interviews to estimate who has committed conservation crimes. To date, both collecting and analyzing indirect survey data has been challenging and practitioners often lack the means to analyze their findings in a scientifically sound manner. We have addressed this problem by developing an open-source software package that will permit for straightforward analyses.

We have developed new analytical techniques for indirect survey questions designed to reduce response bias for sensitive behaviors such as illegal hunting. More powerful and robust analytical methods permit for more accurate quantification of illegal harvesting. We have developed a mathematical model leveraging simple demographic parameters that can be easily obtained even for data-poor wildlife populations; this framework would allow managers and researchers to anticipate how hunter functional responses to catch rates would impact the entire suite of co-harvested species. As such, the supported research  provides new tools and conceptual grounds for rendering conservation policy more robust and responsive to socioeconomic changes.
